block.p: Big Insurer to Compensate Blacks Who Paid Too Much After decades of paying higher premiums for life insurance than white customers, nearly five million black customers and their families nationwide are going to be compensated in a settlement reached with American General, one of the nation's biggest insurers.

The company said that it was making restitution of $206 million, mainly to the black customers and their heirs who, until as recently as April, paid as much as 33 percent more than white customers for small policies intended to cover burial expenses. [Page A1.]

Texas Instruments to Buy a Rival Texas Instruments said it would acquire Burr-Brown, which is also a computer chip maker, for $7.6 billion in stock. [C2.]

Stock Prices Rally as Bonds Fall Microsoft helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 50.65 points, or 1.3 percent, to 4,064.01. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 62.58 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,497.74, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 3.18 points, to 1,479.13. Bond prices fell sharply, with the yield on the 30-year issue rising to 5.96 percent from 5.89 percent on Tuesday. [C11.]

Uranium Enrichment Plant to Close The United States Enrichment Corporation, the private company that runs the nation's only two uranium enrichment plants, said it would close one of them in a year, in Portsmouth, Ohio, because of high costs and a depressed market for reactor fuel. [C22.]

Money Manager Is Suspended Regulators have suspended and fined the former owner of Founders Asset Management, which manages more than $8 billion, for failing to disclose that some of the firm's clients paid excessive commissions on stock trades in the early 1990's. Market Place. [C10.]

A New Standard for Internet Privacy Major Internet companies and the World Wide Web's standard-setting body introduced long-awaited technology that would alert computer users before they visited Web sites that collect more personal information than they are willing to share. The new standard was denounced by some privacy advocates. [C6.]

Protesters Take Control of Nike Site Protesters took control of the Nike Web site and redirected visitors to a site urging organizations to gather at and disrupt a world economic summit later this year. [C2.]

Fidelity Investments Shuffles Staff Fidelity Investments, which manages nearly $1 trillion, shuffled its top executives and reorganized into three units headed by three vice chairmen. James C. Curvey, 65, president and chief operating officer, is leaving both posts and returning to his previous job at the firm. He will remain a vice chairman. Robert L. Reynolds, 48, above, will replace Mr. Curvey as chief operating officer and will also be a vice chairman. Robert C. Pozen, 53, president of FMR, also will be a vice chairman. [C8.]

Frankel Is Sentenced in Germany A German court sentenced Martin R. Frankel, the American financier, to three years in prison for failing to pay custom taxes on smuggled diamonds and carrying false passports. [C4.]

Handspring Shares Climb 35% Shares of Handspring rose 35 percent in their first day of trading after raising $200 million in an initial offering that showed investors' enthusiasm for companies that make increasingly popular hand-held computers. [C22.]

35 Years Later, Hiring Bias Remains More than three decades after the passage of the Civil Rights Act, there is abundant evidence that it did much to improve job prospects for blacks. But bias still persists, and policies aimed at reducing discrimination would be sharper if they concentrated more on opening opportunities than on redressing the grievances of dismissed workers. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. [C2.]
